headline: Sausage Jalapeno Poppers
description: Jalapeno pepper slices are stuffed with a sausage and cream cheese mixture, then wrapped with bacon. They're a spicy, mouthwatering party favorite! Secure the bacon with toothpicks.
name: Sausage Jalapeno Poppers
recipeIngredient: 1 pound sliced bacon, cut in half

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
Place ground sausage in a large, deep skillet. Cook over medium high heat until evenly brown.
Drain sausage and place in a medium bowl. Mix with the cream cheese.
Cut jalapenos in half lengthwise. Remove the seeds. Stuff each jalapeno half with equal portions of the sausage and cream cheese mixture. Wrap with half slices of bacon. Secure bacon with toothpicks.
Arrange wrapped jalapenos in a large, shallow baking dish. Bake in the preheated oven 20 minutes, or until the bacon is evenly brown.

review.reviewBody: Love, love, love this. Thanks for the recipe. I fried the bacon, then crumbled and added it to the sausage cream cheese mixture. How anyone could not like these, I'll never know!
I made this recipe 4 days ago and I'm making it again tomorrow. it's amazing. friggin tasty.
Easy to make and so delicious
Everyone loved it!
best ever always a hit. and it fun to watch there face when they take the first bit.
I will definitely make these again. These poppers were a huge hit for the superbowl and will assuredly make an appearance at the next potluck!
Very tasty , I cooked them just as recipe stated
Delicious! I believe I baked mine a bit longer...otherwise they’re perfect.

Delicious! I also added in a little garlic and onion powders to the cream cheese mixture and baked them a little longer than called for to crisp them up nicely. These were such a hit that hubby is still talking about them~YUM! Thanks for sharing. :)
They were delicious and easy to make. I will definitely save this recipe and make them again!

Meh, I thought you would have tasted more of the sausage but you really didn't. Think next time instead of regular cream cheese I'll go with the flavored jalapeño cream cheese and omit the sausage. Honestly I have had better poppers than this one.

I use 1/2 pound hot Italian sausage, a combination of regular cream cheese and pineapple cream cheese, green onion and about 1/2 cup grated cheddar cheese for 15 jalapenos (30 poppers). The best way I have found to wrap with bacon is to microwave a couple of pieces at a time for 45 seconds and then pat off excess grease on paper towels. I then cut the bacon in half length wise and the in half cross wise giving you 4 pieces out of one slice. I then rub a little honey on each piece and wrap around pepper and securing with a toothpick. These freeze well. Bake straight from freezer on foil lined pan for easy clean up.
Tried this as an alternative for my traditional poppers made on the grill. It was eaten, but we felt the sausage was a bit of an overkill for us. Thanks for sharing.
They were not hot (spicy) enough for the group of party attendees who like spicy food.
delicious... incredible! nothing to change. I use applewood bacon

Need to precook bacon more so it gets crispy or turn the jalapeños over carefully and broil on both sides next time. Other than that I used hot sausage which spiced it up a bit and 60 of them were gone in less than 30 minutes so they were a huge hit
Not my favorite. I made these for the super bowl and it just didn't impress me. Not a keeper.
Make these every year for superbowl and they are a huge success. I do add cheddar cheese before the bacon. Thanks for posting..we love them!

People always ask to make sure I bring these to BBQs. They are so delicious. Everyone is always surprised to fine the sausage in the cream cheese. If you have a mixer I have found that's the easiest way to mix the cream cheese and sausage. If you cream cheese hasn't thawed added the warm sausage to it and it will mix very easily.

I made these for my daughters wedding in addition to the caterers menu. They were the first thing gone! I got everyone commenting on how good they were. I make them all the time now when entertaining. Their delish!!!

These are amazing poppers and huge hit at the party we attended. I broiled them on a cooling rack, on a cookie sheet, but still ended up have to turn them over to get the bottoms crispy. Definitely take the extra step and crisp the bottoms.
Leave bacon whole

09-27-15 ~ Another popper recipe we really enjoyed. I had 9 big jalapeños that need to be used up. I scaled the recipe back and used eight of them. The bacon was thick pepper bacon and my DH grilled them rather than baking them. Loved the added sausage in the cream cheese mixture. Served with 'Bronco Burgers' from AR and grilled peppers, onions and potatoes. Loved that all items were cooked on the grill. Made for easy-peasy clean up. (5-stars)
We made this recipe with cocktail sausages in the peppers with the cream cheese flavored with paprika and cayenne. Wrapped in bacon, they were smoked. GREAT!

My husband LOVES these jalapenos! I've been making these for years now & always mix up the recipe. 
Sometimes I add a blend of three cheeses, other times, after i stuff the pepper, i'll cover the top with shredded mozzarella cheese then proceed to wrap them & sprinkle them with a bit of salt & pepper. 
ENJOY! :)

I made these at a family gathering, and they were AWESOME! Even the little kids loved them. A few tips: they're delicious grilled, but if you bake them, be sure to use a broiler pan or a rack. Boil or partially cook the bacon first, and broil at the end for a few minutes to crisp it up, if necessary. Where gloves through the whole process (my 13 year old was pinching off bits of the raw sausage for me to stuff the peppers, and got completely oogied out by the slimy feeling.) To keep them as mild as possible, but with great flavor, make sure you completely remove ALL the seeds and the ribs. A pretty time-consuming appetizer, but totally worth it. YUMMO!!!!!!

I love this appetizer. They always go so fast. Make sure to wear gloves as your hands will burn for hours. I like to cut the bacon long ways to make sure it wraps around it. This last time s just cut them down the middle and laid them on top.

I made these two nights in a row. The fist night was for a BBQ, the next night just for my family. I used onion and chive flavored cream cheese and barbequed them on medium-low until the bacon was crispy. I also used whole slices bacon. They were amazing.

Very good recipe as it is. I have also made this with a few changes-- sour cream instead of cream cheese makes it more savory than sweet, added pepper jack cheese, white cheddar and sharp cheddar into the sausage mix. Added cayenne, cajun, onion powder & minced garlic for more spicy pop. Also wrapped in one whole slice of hickory smoked bacon intead of half & baked on a rack so that they don't sit in juices and get soggy. Thanks for the great recipe!
Made these my last Cinco de Mayo party and they were gone before any other appetizers. Many requests for them. Will be making again this year. Didn't change a thing.

I've made this recipe twice and it was recommended by my son. These were made while camping using indirect heat on our BBQ grill. I cooked them on aluminum pans so no clean up. 
These did take longer than the 60 minutes but the second time I prepped the jalapeños at home. I used hot Chorizo from my favorite butcher and it was not hot at all. The next time I make these, I will precook the bacon so it will crisp a little faster. 
No one in camp was disappointed from the youngest 8 year old to us older folks. 
I will definitely make these again using one of the previous tips by precooking the bacon a little before wrapping just to help crisp the bacon. Thanks for the recipe it's awesome.
Love these! I made these for the super bowl..all gone! Wear gloves and keep submerged in water while scooping out the seeds. Thank you for the great recipe!

These were ok. My family ate some of them, but a lot were left over. Very good advice about wearing gloves when getting the seeds out of the jalapenos, and doing so under water. My daughter was the one cutting and cleaning them without gloves. Poor baby looked like she was sprayed with pepper spray for hours. Both of our hands were also burning for hours. So not worth the end result imo.

These were a huge hit at our New Years Party. Contrary to what others say I found these very easy to make and it took little time. The longest part is cleaning the peppers. Be sure to where gloves and clean out all those seeds. This are yummy and I will make again. I did add a small bit of cheddar cheese at the bottom of a few of the peppers before putting in the stuffing mix and instead of wrapping them with bacon, I just topped them with a small slice of bacon and let the bacon brown on top,. Yummy indeed.

These turned out GREAT!!! I made them for a party my wife I were invited to where we didn't know very many people. I made a lot of new friends by sharing the recipe! I followed a few tips from other posters that helped: I cleaned the jalapenos under water in a dish, I microwaved the bacon to get it started, I put a touch of honey on the bacon as well (you could taste the touch of sweetness), and I broiled the poppers for 5 minutes after the suggested 20 minutes of cook time, which made my bacon a bit crisper and gave a better presentation. Some advice though, be careful washing any dishes the jalapenos touch. The next day I washed the bowl (without gloves) that I cleaned them in and my hands burned for over an hour. :)

I am making these wonderful poppers as I write this. I go to a neighborhood bar on the weekends to watch football. About a year ago I brought these poppers and WOW what a response. These and my banana cupcakes are the most requested things that I make. When I get there at about 3:00 today it will be standing room only. The owner of the bar lets me bring them (even though he has a kitchen and serves "bar food") because they are so popular and he does a ton of business because I bring good eats.

I made this yesterday it was a hit with the family. I did precook bacon in microwave as suggested and that caused shrinkage so I cut the bacon in half and placed over the top. Worked great. Thanks for the recipe!

I have made this recipe a ton of times and everyone loves it! I also struggled with soft bacon so I kept tweaking it. I do not wrap them in bacon anymore. Instead, while they are cooking I fry and crumble the bacon. I grate 1/4 cup of parmesan cheese into a bowl and then add the (cooled) bacon. The last five minutes of baking I add the cheese and bacon mixture to the top of the peppers and broil for a few minutes. This is the best way I have found to get the crunch of the bacon.

I pretty much followed this recipe just used a little less cream cheese. Also I happened to find jalapeno bacon at food lion. It made the flavor explode!!! They were amazing. Everybody loved them. Thanx

his weekend I went on a quest to find the perfect popper. I cooked up several different batches for a party and this was the favorite stuffing. The sausage gives the filling a firmer texture and a delicious taste! I did some of these in the oven and some on the BBQ. I high recommend the BBQed version! The BBQ gives the bacon a delicious flavor and really makes these “pop”!

Nice easy popper recipe however I did use shredded cheddar cheese as we do not like a cream cheese popper.
Idea and prep and can be suited to anyone's personal taste.

Tried the recipe and loved the poppers. The second time I forgot to purchase cream cheese. I substituted Pimento cheese spread and from this point forward I will be using Pimento cheese. I left out bacon bits; my preference. I also cooked 15 minutes instead of 20 minutes.

These are awesome and are always very popular at parties, if they make it there. We use chorizo for extra spice, and leave off the bacon (we are bacon fanatics, but with the chorizo, it's not really necessary...especially if you plan to eat 10 and don't want to regret the calories even more). Believe it or not, these are awesome if you make them with a good canned jalapeno; the kind that comes in a giant can, pickled with carrots, is the best! The brand name escapes me at the moment. Pickled jalapenos and chorizo together make a *very* spicy combination. I love the idea of honey on the bacon, however, so I think I'll try that next time, with regular sausage instead of chorizo.
This is AMAZING. I did some with sausage and some without. I preferred without. They were gone in minutes. :)

This is a good basic recipe. I was in a hurry and didn't have time to get to the store to get the exact ingredients, so made this recipe with I had. I used chopped shrimp instead of sausage, used a spinach and artichoke cream cheese and added an 8 oz tub of sour cream. If you like your bacon done, count on leaving it in the oven an extra 10+ minutes to brown up. After loading up all the jalapeños, I still had a bit of the mixture left, so I put it out as a chip dip. It was all pretty tasty!

i used italian seasoned turkey sausage and added some cheddar... REALLY GOOD!!! I was asked to make them again for our next party... Super easy... but be sure to use gloves... my hands burned for a day after handeling them without gloves.
AMAZING!! I made these for a potluck and they disappeared! I know what I'll be making for the Superbowl : )

These are my most asked for appetizer. I add a half an onion to the cooking sausage and while the sausage is still hot I add the cream cheese to it with my hands; then stuff, wrap and bake. Be sure to make enough.
Big hit at every party. I usually grill them outside on a charcoal grill, the bacon comes out crispy.

This was just okay for us. I ended up adding cumin and taco seasoning to spice it up some. It was just for our family so I just placed the bacon on top rather than wrapping and I think is actually a good way to go. This was after putting the bacon in the microwave as others had suggested. It was good after our own favorite seasonings and will make it again with these additions.
Mmmmmmmm. Yum, made these, ate these, shared these. I loved them, everyone loved them. I didn't add the bacon, still good though. YUM

I made these, used jimmy dean hot sausage, added a can of drained rotel tomatoes and diced green chilis, and precooked the bacon just enough so it would get crispy, OMG!!! everyone raved about them, I will make this again and again, perfect! Really Perfect!! Not spicy just a really good flavor!
There are never any left overs when I make these. The best compliment ever.

I have been making these for years, I sometimes substitute the sausage and use shrimp. Just fill with cream cheese, place a shrimp on top and wrap with bacon. I precook the bacon a little so it crisps up with out over cooking the shrimp.

YUM!!!!!! I made these for a superbowl party and they were a big hit!! to add some flavor to the cream cheese - sausage mix, i added about a table spoon of dry ranch dip seasoning and wrapped with applewood smoked bacon to offset the jalapeno! Will def make again!
Very good simple recipe. I will serve this at every get together from now on. Yum yum give me some!

Great recipe...I found a jalapeno baking rack at amazon($14), that lets you cook them upright! Just cut the tops off, core them, stuff, wrap with bacon...enjoy. Also, to help cut down on the grease I partially cooked the bacon in the frying pan, then used a paper towel to soak up the excess grease before wrapping around the pepper.Yummy:)
SOOOO rocking good! I put a little tiny bit of maple syrup on top of each popper before putting them in the oven. It made them the perfect mix of salty and sweet. Can't stop eating these!

SO GOOD!!! Stuffing jalapenos is what I call a labor of food love, but this recipe is worth the time and effort. I cut the recipe in half for two of us, but I accidentally used a full piece of bacon on each jalapeno, which, as my husband said, was not a bad mistake at all. The jalapenos at the market happened to be huge, so a full piece of bacon covered each half perfectly without toothpicks. To the cream cheese mixture I added ground garlic and onion, salt, cilantro, green onion, and some shredded cheddar cheese. I baked these on a rack at 375 degrees for about 55 minutes. I was concerned that the cream cheese filling would run out, but it did not. 

For those who have not worked with fresh chilies before, get yourself a box of rubber gloves before you make this recipe. I also wear glasses and sometimes wear a mask over my nose and mouth if the chilies are particularly hot. Cutting them under water is an excellent method. I find that with a glove on, I can easily scrape the insides out with my thumbnail. You don't fully respect the power of these little guys until they hurt you, and then the pain lasts for hours. This includes touching them and inhaling the fumes. Beware that they have oils in them so that even after you wash your hands, you can still rub your eye and be in trouble. I have learned all of this the hard way. Just be cautious!

Thanks so much for the excellent recipe. These are a real treat!!
Turned out absolutely perfect! Lots of work but they were a big hit :D

I just tried this recipe and I was really surprised how easy it was. I halved the recipe because it was just me and my son that will eat them. I added a little ranch dressing mix and diced red, orange, and yellow bell pepper only because I had it sitting in the fridge. I think the additions for this recipe are only limited by your imagination. I followed other reviewers ideas about microwaving the bacon first. Easy to do and delicious. Thanks for this keeper.
I've made sooo many different kind of poppers but when i made these everyone went crazy over them!! Very good flavors, very good recipe. Two thumbs up

i made this to take to my new inlaws bbq. I was nervous- but they went over great. i was told i had to bring these to every bbq they throw! yeah. helpful hint tho- wear gloves!!! slice under water to keep fumes from getting into your eyes. also cook bacon just a little longer in microwave.
This is how I make my Poppers. The only difference with mine is that I throw them on the grill. This is the BEST recipe!!!!
This isa great Super Bowl treat!! I like to add a little Lowry;s Seasoning salt and a touch of garlic..

I have been making these for years! They are excellent.We call them Armadillo Eggs because we use a whole slice of bacon to wrap them, and when they cook down in the oven the look like egg shaped armadillo shells, lol. Also have found at my parties that the guys love to pile these on a burger!
 The nice thing is if you are making them for people who can't handle jalapenos, you can substitute any kind of peppers. I have used banana peppers, goat horns, anahiems, pablanos, anything. The pablanos are hotter than a bell pepper but not a great deal, they are much larger, we have made them as an entree!

I have been making this for years, Except I make a lowfat version. Use Honeysuckle White Breakfast Turkey Sausage (comes in rolls) and Fat Free Cream Cheese. And the lowest fat bacon (but real bacon) that you can find. It comes out better, I think and you don't feel so guilty!
So Good!!

Everyone loves them! I cannot make enough!! Two things I do is only add half the sausage and bake them on a rack. The rack allows the bacon grease to drop down and the bacon to cook better all the way around instead of becoming greasy.

These get consumed so fast I'm not sure I've even tried one!
After running out of bacon, I put the remaining spread in a bowl and stuck halved jalapeño shells in as dippers-for those that like it really hot!

I make a version of this but I use Jimmy Dean hot sausage, chop it up in skillet as it is browning, I mix the cream cheese and add 1/2 pack of real bacon bits instead of wrapping it with bacon. I don't like them real hot so I also scrape the white membrane from the pepper under cold water. Once you start eating these you will not want to stop until they are all gone.
This was fantastic. Very huge hit at the party. I listened to others and brushed honey all over the bacon as well as microwaved the bacon for a min. Awesome dish
Alot of work but worth it.
Awesome Poppers! make them all the time!!
This was so good. I used the precooked bacon which worked out great and made it so much quicker to prepare. This was a favorite for my friend. Keep in mind you much use gloves when preparing peppers.

Fixed these for our Church BBQ. I made them the night before and then put them on a charcoal grill with very low heat, to keep them from burning and just enough heat to warm them up. Everyone just loved them. The hardest part was cleaning the peppers and getting all the vein out so they wouldn't be so hot no one could eat them. All and all, THEY WERE GREAT !!

I made these per the recipe once so far and they were a bit hit. Even my 8 yr-old grand-daughter liked them! Ratrher than wrap the pepper with bacon, I cut the bacon in pieces just long enough to cover the pepper and laid it in top. Fewer calories and still had the bacon flavor. I'll be making them again this weekend. This time I'm going to add some cheddar cheese as suggested below and will use one package of regular and one package of hot sausage to add a little more punch.
Good but alot of work. I think I will stick with the Jalapeno Popper Spread!
Made these - very tasty - it was hard to share.

Yeaaa these were pretty awesome! Took the advice of others and pre-cooked the bacon so it could be cooked all the way through with the finished product. Lots of time and love goes into making these, but they are awesome! YUM.

Simply Amazing! I made these for our office potluck. I was new and wanted to make a good impression. They were the crowd favorite and now I'm recognized as jalapeno popper Nancy, lol. Everyone wanted the recipe.

I did add 1/4 tsp. of cayenne pepper and 4 chopped green onions to the cheese mix as well as precooked the bacon and brushed a bit of honey to it before wrapping it. I found the wrapping the pepper with the precooked bacon was a bit difficult, so I ended up just placing a strip lengthwise on top of the jalapeno. Still looked, smelled, and tasted amazingly! Now there is no turning back with requests for these at every company event.

Good make-ahead appetizer! I assembled them and refrigerated them overnight, and added 10 minutes to the cooking time. I used reduced fat sausage and reduced fat cream cheese. I added a cup of reduced fat shredded cheddar to the filling.
 I didn't wear gloves when cutting the jalapenos. It wasn't until 30 minutes later that my skin started to burn (for the next 12 hours). I had to be extremely creative in finding a way to take out my contact lenses! So bottom line, as nice as it is to save a dollar, the gloves are probably a good investment.
 Besides that, I'll make these again. They'd be good for company and they hold up well in the fridge overnight before baking. Very attractive little snacks!

I make this however, I put the raw sausage in the jalapenos and sprinkle onion and garlic powder on it...wrap in raw maple bacon...gives great flavor. In the summer we cook them on the grill, in the winter bake in the oven about 375 until sauasage and bacon are cooked and peppers are less hot the longer you cook them.

I like to precook the bacon and crumble it right into the filling as well as adding a little shredded cheese and fresh cilantro if I have it. I precook the jalapenos for just a few minutes before filling them then popping under the broiler until the cheese is bubbly. Problem solved!
These are very good, but the bacon never gets done as quickly as the recipes suggests.

Excellent recipe but needs clarification as to cook time and fill amount. I followed the recipe exactly and these are my findings:

1) FILL AMOUNT: Very hard to fill 60 half jalapenos without knowing how much to fill them. My advice would be to fill them so they're more than filled flat but don't try to hump the filling to reconstruct the size of the original jalapeno. A gentle arc over the top for each one will fill them all. First time I had too much filling; second time I had too little. 

2) COOK TIME: The bacon needs far more than 20 minute (like 45 here) to crisp. Basically after that time I took them out but they were still soggy on one side. I honestly think you need to turn these to get the bacon crisp. 

I used a large turkey size roasting pan wrapped in foil, and a flat rack sitting on top, so the bacon grease would drain. You DO NOT want the poppers lying around in the bacon fat or they will not bake, they will attempt to fry and won't get hot enough to do so. Even on a rack, bacon remained soggy. I wonder if I should have used higher heat.

Also, with this arrangement I still needed to cook these in two batches.

I used "thick" bacon. I used "breakfast sausage," locally made, and in a plastic tube, singly wrapped (ie., no casing). I used fairly large sized jalapenos. 

SUMMARY: Once you have figured out the cook time and fill level, you will have an excellent jalapeno popper. Feeds an army.
me and my husband love this recipe wont change a thing
Made these for BBQ, everybody loved them! I placed them under the broiler for a minute to give the bacon a good crisp top and made the cheese brown and bubbly!
These were a hit at our swim party. I did pre-cook the bacon in the microwave then finished it up in the oven. There were no leftovers.
Love this recipe but I do agree with others that you should cook your bacon slightly before. Turned out GREAT!
OMG!!! is all I have to say.

I read alot of recipes with sausage so I gave it a try and thought it was awful. I am used to the Best Ever Jalapeno Poppers that use bacon and a breading. Bacon bits (the real kind) are SO MUCH better than sausage. I will stick with bacon.
They were good, but not what I expected from reading the reviews. I agree about the amount of bacon called for, I had to buy more than one pack.

These are wonderful!!! I have made these several times and I have taken the suggestions of the other reviews. I have found the best way to clean and de-seed the peppers is to use a melon baller and for me this is the easiest way to prep the peppers. I have also added some cayenne pepper to the cream cheese and sausage mixture. I also pre-cook the microwave for just a few minutes prior to wrapping the peppers. I have also drizzled honey over the peppers prior to baking in the oven and have always received rave reviews.
Tasty, but a little messy for entertaining groups of people

I love this recipe. The peppers are not too spicy for the kids with the yummy cream cheese inside. Definitely use 1/2 slices of bacon (1/3 if very fatty) so the bacon flavor won't overpower the other ingredients.
They were good.
I thought I had planted too many jalapeno pepper plants... Trying this recipe makes me think ... I did't plant enough! Great recipe! I didn't have bacon so I used canadian bacon .

I have made these a couple times, they are great! Has anyone ever made these ahead of time and froze them, baking later for a quick appetizer? I was thinking about trying that but am worried they might turn out watery and ruining the whole batch, any suggestions? Thanks!
